summary: Guided Historical Tour
locationaddress: Low Library, 535 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Tour,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Guided Historical Tour,Visitors Center,org/visitorscenter,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees
description: <p>Join this tour to learn more about the history, architecture, and sculpture of Columbia and the Morningside Heights campus. Whether you&#39;re an amateur New York City historian or visiting campus for the first time, you will leave the tour knowing more about our storied past.</p>\n<p>Tours will depart from the Visitors Center, located in Room 213 in Low Library.&nbsp;Please arrive at least 15 minutes prior to the tour time. Tours take place rain or shine. We encourage guests to dress appropriately based upon the weather conditions of their visit day.</p>\n<p>All Visitors Center visitors are required to bring proof of a primary vaccination series to their campus tour. A list of acceptable documentation can be found <a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/content/faqs-regarding-covid-19-vaccination#!#%2Fcu_accordion_item-4780" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>

summary: Film Screening & Discussion. "Youth"
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <h2>Important Note</h2>\n<p><strong>Registration required. Please note that all attendees must follow Columbia&rsquo;s&nbsp;<a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">COVID-19 Policies and Guidelines</a>. Columbia University is committed to protecting the health and safety of its community.&nbsp; To that end,&nbsp;<strong>all visiting alumni and guests</strong>&nbsp;must meet the University requirement of full vaccination status in order to attend in-person events.&nbsp; Vaccination cards may be checked upon entry to all venues.&nbsp;</strong></p>\n<p>Please join us for the screening of&nbsp;<em>Youth&nbsp;</em>(2022) and a Zoom Q&amp;A discussion with the film director&nbsp;<strong>Dmitrii Davydov</strong>. Hailing from the Sakha Republic, Davydov is the director of the prize-winning drama&nbsp;<em>Scarecrow&nbsp;</em>(2020) which popularized Yakut cinema both in the festival circuit and the regional box-office. Premiering in January 2023,&nbsp;<em>Youth</em>&nbsp;is Davydov&rsquo;s latest film, a witty and refreshing musical comedy set in a small town in Yakutia. Puting the denizens of the periphery in the spotlight, Youth tells a story of a home-coming with warmth and good-humor. &nbsp;<em>Youth&nbsp;</em>is the second movie of the Spring 2023 Harriman Film Series&nbsp;<em>Peripheral Vision,&nbsp;</em>which explores the anti-imperial gaze in contemporary Russian cinema.&nbsp;Screening and discussion moderated by&nbsp;<a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/mark-lipovetsky/"><strong>Mark Lipovetsky</strong></a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/tatiana-efremova/"><strong>Tatiana Efremova</strong></a>.</p>

summary: Multi-Faith Fellowship
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Multi-Faith Fellowship provides the rare opportunity for genuine learning and community across faith traditions. Honesty, openness, and humility are core values that make the Multi-Faith Fellowship a unique experience in education and dialogue. Students from all schools and all traditions are welcome to join. Join us for&nbsp;dinner, discussion, and multi-faith dialogue every Wednesday night throughout the semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><a href="https://religiouslife.columbia.edu/content/multi-faith-fellowship" target="_blank">Learn more and apply to be a fellow here</a>.</p>

summary: ME Seminar: Dr. Cynthia Hajal
locationaddress: Mudd Hall, 500 W. 120 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Tissue Engineering Models for Cancer and Drug Delivery</p>\n<p>Brain cancers are among the most fatal with a five-year survival rate of only 30%. This is due to their rapid growth rate, ability to develop resistance to chemotherapy, and the difficulties in transporting therapeutics across the blood-brain barrier (BBB), one of the tightest blood vessel barriers in humans. The lack of physiologically relevant in vitro human brain tumor models and the challenges in translating results from animal experiments to the clinic have greatly hindered progress in improving patient outcomes. We employ novel design strategies to engineer in vitro microfluidic brain cancer models and 3D tumor models from patient tissues to address this critical need. These platforms enable us to study tumor development in the brain, design new targeted nano-therapies for cancer, and understand the genetic mechanisms of resistance to chemotherapy. Our human-like tissue engineering models provide highly relevant pre-clinical tools that can be used to understand tumor progression and drug delivery, leading to better cancer patient outcomes.</p>\n<p>Cynthia Hajal is a postdoctoral research fellow in the lab of Dr. Keith Ligon at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, with joint appointments at the Broad Institute and Harvard Medical School. She is building 3D brain tumor models from patient tissues to study the genetic mechanisms of resistance to chemotherapy. Prior to this, Cynthia received her S.M. and Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering from MIT, where she worked in the lab of Dr. Roger Kamm to develop microfluidic models of the brain blood vessels and other organ systems to study cancer progression and drug delivery. Cynthia earned her B.S. in Mechanical Engineering and B.A. in Economics from Columbia University. During this time, she worked as a research assistant in the labs of Drs. James Hone and Michael Sheetz, where she designed nanoscale pillars for mechanosensing at the cellular scale. In her future lab, Cynthia will leverage her expertise in fluids, mechanics, and genetics to design complex microfluidic models of the tumor microenvironment to study cancer progression and drug delivery. These tissue engineering models will advance our understanding of cancer and drug delivery. They will be used to gain a more comprehensive insight into the impact of the tumor microenvironment on cancer.</p>

summary: Pizza with your Prof: The Fight for Climate Justice
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>This Pizza with your Prof event will be an intimate conversation on the effectiveness of climate action, between ISHR faculty&nbsp;<a href="http://www.humanrightscolumbia.org/profile/staff/jackie-dugard#overlay-context=about/staff">Jackie Dugard</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://www.humanrightscolumbia.org/profile/faculty/noah-chasin%20">Noah Chasin</a>, and guest speaker&nbsp;<a href="http://scienceandsociety.columbia.edu/directory/lydia-gibson">Lydia Gibson</a>. Our professors will discuss how human rights practitioners, climate activists, and scholars combat climate change, from strategic litigation at the international level, to environmentally-conscious urban planning and design in NYC, to addressing challenges of data justice and epistemic violence to marginalized communities.&nbsp;</p>

summary: Virtual Naloxone Training - Open to all Columbia affiliates
locationaddress: Online
description: <p>Columbia Health is a Registered Opioid Overdose Prevention Program, recognized by New York City and State Departments of Health. This designation came as part of a collaboration with researchers from the Mailman School of Public Health and the School of General Studies. As part of this work, Columbia Health is offering virtual Naloxone training via Zoom to members of the Columbia University community. Naloxone kits&nbsp;can be picked up from Columbia Health or mailed to participants upon completion of training.&nbsp;If you would like to learn more about the training, please visit&nbsp;<a href="https://health.columbia.edu/content/naloxone-training">https://health.columbia.edu/content/naloxone-training</a>.</p>\n<p>Registration required.</p>\n<p><strong>Register for the March 2, 2:00 &ndash; 3:00 PM ET&nbsp;session:</strong> <a href="https://nam02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2F3XBgOPp&amp;data=05%7C01%7Chealthcomm%40cumc.columbia.edu%7Cdd8cc8229d8741a92a0408dafe249cc0%7Cb0002a9b0017404d97dc3d3bab09be81%7C0%7C0%7C638101730462242405%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&amp;sdata=d4Ymsoc2bAe6R6m2WBpNxbySyeifDA6mbiyZCEJ5rYM%3D&amp;reserved=0">https://bit.ly/3XBgOPp</a></p>

summary: A Sneak Peek: Integrity at the CSSI
description: <p>In this virtual session, you will get a preview into the new Center for Student Success and Intervention. You will have an opportunity to meet and engage with some of the staff members and learn more about their passion for helping students through various challenges.<br />\nWe take pride in building relationships with our students as we work together to uphold the integrity and values of the University.alumni event.</p>

summary: Yoga Class
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Take a break to relax and refresh with yoga in Earl Hall. Free yoga classes (open level) will be offered in the Auditorium in Earl Hall every&nbsp;Thursday evening&nbsp;during the fall 2022 semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>No pre-registration required;&nbsp;open to all Columbia University students. Please bring your own mat and arrive 5-10 minutes early to sign in and set up.&nbsp;There is a 5 minute late policy, doors close at 7:05pm, or when the room has reached max capacity. 75 students maximum.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Please note that after spring break, the yoga classes will be offered from 5-6pm for the rest of the semester.&nbsp;</p>

summary: Composer Portraits: Øyvind Torvund
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Norwegian composer &Oslash;yvind Torvund relies on his classical compositional training as much as his background as a guitarist in rock and improvising groups in his work. His music is simultaneously quirky, serious, frenetic, and shimmering, and reveals an expansive sonic language, incredible orchestration, and the juxtaposition of the expected and unexpected. An all-star cast of new music artists join together to perform a program of recent works including two premieres.</p>

summary: HRI Presents: Women, Conflict and International Humanitarian Law
locationaddress: Columbia Law School, 435 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: org/lawhri,org/law,International and Public Affairs,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Lecture,Law,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Clinical Health Sciences,Panel,Social Justice,Postdocs,Global Programs,Government and Public Policy,Prospective Students,Discussion,Graduate Students,Trainees,Political Science
description: <p>Gender inequality remains a reality in every country worldwide, and is particularly pronounced in conflict-affected contexts. How do inequalities and gender roles shape civilian experiences &ndash; namely,&nbsp;women&rsquo;s experiences - of war? What are the responsibilities of those who hold power to shift the needle?&nbsp;Amid growing inequalities this topic may never have been so urgent.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Join us for a critical reflection with the new President of the&nbsp;ICRC&nbsp;on how&nbsp;international&nbsp;humanitarian&nbsp;law&nbsp;and&nbsp;humanitarian&nbsp;principles can be a vital link between&nbsp;women, peace and security and address the gendered impacts of war. This is an HRI-sponsored event. Lunch will be provided.&nbsp;</p>

summary: Peru: from perpetual crisis to tipping point?
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Latin America,org/ilas,Postdocs,Government and Public Policy,Prospective Students,Discussion,Graduate Students,Trainees,Political Science
description: <p><strong>Peru: from perpetual crisis to tipping point?</strong></p>\n<p>Speaker: Alberto Vergara</p>\n<p>Alberto Vergara is a professor at the Department of Social and Political Sciences at the Universidad del Pac&iacute;fico (Lima, Peru). He received his PhD from University of Montreal and he was a Trudeau Foundation doctoral fellow. Previously, he was a post-doctoral researcher at Harvard University supported by a Banting Fellowship. Dr. Vergara has been a lecturer in Latin American politics at Harvard University and Sciences Po, Paris. His research has appeared in the Journal of Democracy, Latin American Research Review, and the Journal of Politics in Latin America, among others. His most recent book is La Danza Hostil: Poderes subnacionales y Estado central en Bolivia y Per&uacute; (1952-2012) (The hostile dance: subnational powers and central state in Bolivia and Peru). He is the author of numerous non-academic essays and occasional pieces, many gathered in the book Ciudadanos sin Rep&uacute;blica (Citizens without a Republic). Dr. Vergara&rsquo;s work focuses primarily on representation, accountability, and subnational politics. During his fellowship, he focused on the Peruvian party &ldquo;Fujimorismo&rdquo; as a way to rethink the relation between democracy and political parties.</p>

summary: CTLgrads Office Hours (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>We invite current Columbia graduate student with&nbsp;questions about teaching&nbsp;to drop by office hours anytime today from 2:00&ndash;4:00 pm. We also welcome conversations about CTL fellowships, programs, services, job market preparation, and making progress in the Teaching Development Program (tdp.ctl.columbia.edu).</p>\n<p>No appointment is necessary; you can join us in-person in 212 Butler Library, or via Zoom at https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/my/ctlgrads.</p>\n<p>If&nbsp;you can&#39;t make office hours but want support, you can request an individual consultation at http://bit.ly/ctl-gradconsult or email us at CTLgrads@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: Graduate School Coffee Chat: International & Public Affairs
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Interested in learning more about graduate school in public policy? Whether you are a first-year exploring your interests or an upperclassman wanting to apply, join ILAS and LASA for a coffee chat with current SIPA graduate students to learn more about applying to policy school, academic/student life in graduate school, and have any questions you might have answered! This event is a continuation of ILAS&#39;s Undergraduate/Graduate mentorship program.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Snacks will be provided!</p>\n<p><strong>Co-sponsored by the Latin American Student Association (LASA) at Columbia&#39;s School of International &amp; Public Affairs</strong></p>

summary: Sean Jones Quartet
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The internationally acclaimed trumpeter Sean Jones &ldquo;combines artistry and virtuosity, with a sound reminiscent of vintage Freddie Hubbard and Lee Morgan yet completely modern&rdquo;&nbsp;<em>(Jazz Times)</em>. The former lead trumpeter of the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, Jones is a musical chameleon, adept in all styles and genres. He brings his quartet to the stage for his Miller debut.</p>

summary: EE Seminar: Robust Gallium Nitride (GaN) Heterostructure Microelectr
locationaddress: Schapiro CEPSR, 530 W. 120 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p><strong>Abstract:</strong>&nbsp;As we look to move beyond traditional silicon semiconductor technology, wide-bandgap gallium nitride (GaN) micro/nanoelectronics have emerged as a promising alternative. GaN device technology is poised to revolutionize high-power and high-frequency applications. Additionally, GaN can unlock new application spaces for electronic systems that are currently constrained by the lack of robust semiconductor devices for harsh environments. While silicon technology is limited to moderate temperatures, GaN electronics have demonstrated a vast temperature range of operation from cryogenic to 1000&deg;C. Devices that can achieve reliable operation under these conditions have applications in the space, energy and environment, automotive, and defense sectors, as well as quantum computing.</p>\n<p>In this seminar, I will describe the design and microfabrication of indium aluminum nitride/gallium nitride (InAlN/GaN) high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs), which leverage a two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) conducting channel.&nbsp; The lattice-matched InAlN/GaN heterostructure can enable co-fabrication of sensors and peripheral read-out circuitry on a single monolithically integrated chip.&nbsp; Advances in techniques to improve high temperature performance reliability in InAlN/GaN HEMTs, such as the development of novel contact metallization schemes and geometries, will be discussed. Recent compelling developments in high-temperature capable solid-state 2DEG devices and piezoelectric MEMS resonators up to 600&deg;C in air for extended durations will be presented. This work has resulted in the first demonstration of an uncooled GaN device successfully operating&nbsp;<em>in situ</em>&nbsp;the harsh environmental conditions found on the surface of Venus with the goal of enabling long duration robotic planetary exploration. These contributions support the use of the GaN heterostructure and provide a road map for further maturing this semiconductor platform. Finally, I will conclude by discussing the exciting future landscape of GaN and other wide-bandgap microelectronics for the development of critical next generation &ldquo;beyond silicon&quot; technologies.</p>\n<p><strong>Biography:</strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong>Dr. Savannah Eisner received the B.S. degree in electrical engineering from Villanova University in 2017, and the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in electrical engineering from Stanford University in 2020 and 2023, respectively.&nbsp; Her dissertation research focused on the use of uncooled GaN transistors for extreme environment space applications. She is currently a postdoctoral researcher in the Extreme Environment Microsystems Laboratory (XLab) in the Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics at Stanford University. Her research interests include the design of wide-bandgap micro/nanoelectronic sensors and systems. Dr. Eisner was a National Science Foundation (NSF) Graduate Research Fellow and a Future Technical Leaders Fellow of the NSF engineering research center for power optimization and electro-thermal systems. She is the recipient an IEEE Aerospace Best Paper Award for her work on GaN microelectronics for future Venus surface missions.</p>

description: <p>Immerse yourself in the Chinese language this summer! Join the Center for Undergraduate Global Engagement and head instructors from the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures on Monday, March 6th, from 12:00 PM - 1:00 PM as we discuss this virtual Summer 2023 program. This intensive virtual Chinese language program offers all levels of Chinese, from elementary to advanced. Classes will be taught by the faculty from the Columbia Chinese Language Program, who will offer live, highly interactive instruction. Learn more about how you can improve your Chinese language skills on this intensive, virtual summer program! Zoom Link: https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/j/96402305186?pwd=YWhqWE5NMnAvS2hQclBtclFCVEszdz09</p>

summary: Breastfeeding Basics: For Home and Work/School
locationaddress: Hammer Health Sciences Center, 701 W. 168 St., New York, NY 10032
description: <p>This is an educational workshop for expectant and new mothers who want to breastfeed their babies when they return to work or school. Participants will learn breastfeeding basics, including common difficulties and how to manage them, and return-to-work/school strategies and resources. &nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>Presenter: </strong>Heather McFadden is an International Board Certified Lactation Consultant and is currently serving on the board of the New York Lactation Consultant&#39;s Association (NYLCA). &nbsp;Heather maintains a private practice offering home visits postpartum as well as prenatal breastfeeding classes and is also a member of the lactation staff at NYU Langone hospital.</p>\n<p><em>Spouses/Partners are welcome to attend. Babies are also welcome. In deciding whether to bring your infant, please do what you feel is best for the health and safety of your child and family.</em></p>

summary: Collective Bargaining in Japan & the US
locationaddress: Online
categories: org/law,org/APEC,International and Public Affairs,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Online,Business,Law,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Economics,Panel,Postdocs,Careers,Government and Public Policy,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Graduate School of Arts and Sciences,Trainees
description: <p>Labor unions have recently reappeared in news headlines in Japan and the US as both countries recognize a need to improve employee wages, benefits, and working conditions.&nbsp; However, there is a striking fundamental difference between the two countries. US law requires a majority of employees to support union representation before a company is required to negotiate with the union. That results in high-profile unionization campaigns like those taking place at Amazon warehouses and Starbucks stores.&nbsp; By contrast, employers in Japan must bargain in good faith with minority unions, sometimes more than one at a workplace.&nbsp; How does this affect unionization and collective bargaining, and what are the implications for the future of labor markets in Japan and the US?&nbsp; Two leading experts on labor law, Professor Hiroya Nakakubo of Hitotsubashi University and Professor Alan Hyde of Rutgers Law School, will join NYU Law Adjunct Professor Bruce Aronson in discussion.</p>\n<p><a href="https://nyu.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_4OXCkFiJdSX87f8">Register</a></p>\n<p><em>Co-sponsored by the&nbsp;<a href="https://usali.org/">U.S.-Asia Law Institute</a>&nbsp;(USALI) of New York University School of Law</em></p>

summary: Columbia Summer Research Practicum in Public Humanities
locationaddress: Lerner Hall, 2920 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Information Session,Student,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Columbia College,Columbia Engineering,First-years,First-Generation Students,Transfer Students,Scholarships,Global Programs,Graduate Students,General Studies,org/gs,org/OGPF,Study Abroad,Barnard College
description: Interested in learning more about the emerging field of public humanities? Hear from the Columbia faculty director about how this virtual program provides students with an introduction to modern Greek history and culture, hands-on experience with the methods and tools of public-facing research, and supervised guidance to develop and pursue independent projects using Greece as a vantage point to engage issues in social justice, democracy, and community building. Students from a broad range of disciplines are encouraged to apply. This program is sponsored and funded by the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Public Humanities Initiative (SNFPHI). For more information, please consult the Center for Undergraduate Global Engagement’s website.

summary: A Conversation with author Linda Villarosa
locationaddress: Columbia School of Nursing, 560 W. 168 St., New York, NY 10032
categories: org/SONalumni,org/CUIMCstaff,org/CND,org/CUIMChr,Medical Center,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Student,Faculty,Staff,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Basic Health Sciences,Clinical Health Sciences,Social Sciences,Social Justice,org/universitylife,School of Social Work,Research,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Healthcare,Discussion,Graduate Students,College of Dental Medicine,College of Physicians and Surgeons,Columbia Nursing,Mailman School of Public Health,Trainees,org/cumc_hr,org/cumc,Journalism,Other
description: <p>Join us for a compelling conversation moderated by Assistant Professor of Nursing Dr. Ashley Graham-Perel with journalist and author Linda Villarosa. Villarosa discusses the forces in the American healthcare system and society that cause Black people to &ldquo;live sicker and die quicker&rdquo; than their white counterparts. And, most powerfully, Villarosa describes the new understanding that coping with the daily scourge of racism ages Black people prematurely. Register today</p>

summary: Pop-Up Concerts: The Hands Free
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Hands Free is an acoustic quartet that creates &ldquo;a beautifully eclectic mix of sounds that depict an immense variety of places and emotions&mdash;all while maintaining the warmth and spontaneity of an impromptu jam session&rdquo;&nbsp;<em>(Second Inversion).</em>&nbsp;Making their Miller debut, the group features four unique and imaginative composer/performers creating improvisational works that draw from an eclectic array of influences in classical, jazz, and folk traditions.</p>\n<p><em>Sit onstage and enjoy a free drink during these hour-long weeknight Pop-Ups concerts, and mingle with the musicians and fellow concertgoers after the show. Onstage seating is first-come, first-served.</em></p>\n<p>Free admission &bull; Doors open at 5:30pm, music at 6:00pm</p>

summary: Post-Purim Celebration on the Plaza
locationaddress: Haven Plaza, Haven Avenue between Fort Washington Avenue and 169th Street
categories: Medical Center,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Wellness,Trainees,Community,Cultural,org/CUMCGovComAff,Elected Officials,Festival,Community Health,Washington Heights,Youth,Inwood,Arts and Culture,Programs,org/cumc,Forums,Other
description: <p>In honor of the Purim holiday the Jewish Cultural Employee Resource Groups (JERG) invite you to stop by Haven Plaza for some Hamantaschen, a triangle-shaped pastry!<br />\nPurim also known as the feast of &ldquo;lots,&rdquo; is a joyous Jewish holiday during which commemorates the day Esther, Queen of Persia, bravely exposed her previously hidden Jewish heritage to her husband, the King, and convinced him to save her people form execution at the hands of Haman</p>

summary: Meal Planning for Busy People
locationaddress: Online
description: <p>Maintaining proper nutrition can sometimes be put on the backburner when we have a lot going on. Join us for a discussion with&nbsp;Registered Dietitian, Molly Chanzis, to talk about how to make healthy eating sustainable and realistic. We&rsquo;ll cover healthy eating basics, discuss how to meal plan for yourself and/or a family, and how to keep up with a meal planning routine when life feels super busy.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>Presenter:&nbsp;</strong>Molly Chanzis, MS, RD, CDN, CDCES is a Registered Dietitian who has been practicing for more than 10 years. Molly is passionate about making nutrition attainable to all, and believes in sustainable lifestyle changes instead of quick fixes. She likes to focus on what foods and habits to add to your life, instead of taking things away. You can find Molly on social media&nbsp;<strong>@sayyestothefreshh</strong>&nbsp;where she shares healthy recipes, nutrition tips, and weekly meal plan ideas. She also sees patients through the virtual platform Culina Health.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Join us for an additional event&nbsp;in this&nbsp;semester&#39;s nutrition series!&nbsp; A&nbsp;<a href="https://events.columbia.edu/cal/event/eventView.do?b=de&amp;calPath=%2Fpublic%2Fcals%2FMainCal&amp;guid=CAL-00bbdb70-8595c682-0185-97ff9e44-00003b47events@columbia.edu&amp;recurrenceId=" target="_blank">Live Cooking Demo -&nbsp;Quick Prep Meals with a Registered Dietitian</a> (Wednesday, May 3).&nbsp;</p>

summary: Guided Historical Tour
locationaddress: Low Library, 535 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Tour,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Guided Historical Tour,Visitors Center,org/visitorscenter,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees
description: <p>Join this tour to learn more about the history, architecture, and sculpture of Columbia and the Morningside Heights campus. Whether you&#39;re an amateur New York City historian or visiting campus for the first time, you will leave the tour knowing more about our storied past.</p>\n<p>Tours will depart from the Visitors Center, located in Room 213 in Low Library.&nbsp;Please arrive at least 15 minutes prior to the tour time. Tours take place rain or shine. We encourage guests to dress appropriately based upon the weather conditions of their visit day.</p>\n<p>All Visitors Center visitors are required to bring proof of a primary vaccination series to their campus tour. A list of acceptable documentation can be found <a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/content/faqs-regarding-covid-19-vaccination#!#%2Fcu_accordion_item-4780" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>

summary: CEEM Seminar Series | Youssef Hashash
locationaddress: Schapiro CEPSR, 530 W. 120 St., New York, NY 10027
xproperties:
X-BEDEWORK-REGISTRATION-GUEST-ACCESS : values : text : 	email,X-BEDEWORK-IMAGE : values : text : /public/images/CEEM Seminar Header-202302170147.jpg,X-BEDEWORK-THUMB-IMAGE : values : text : 	/public/images/CEEM Seminar Header-202302170147-thumb.png,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Location/Morningside,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Type/Seminar,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Student,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Postdocs,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Faculty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Graduate Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Category/Engineering,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Alumni,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Family Friendly,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Prospective Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Public,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Staff,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Events open to/Trainees,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-seas_civil/Category/Research,X-BEDEWORK-SUBMITTEDBY : values : text : nr2516 for SEAS - CEEM (agrp_seas_ceem),X-BEDEWORK-DESCRIPTION-FORMAT : values : text : html,X-BEDEWORK-CALSUITE : values : text : SEAS - Civil Engineering and Engineering Mechanics,X-BEDEWORK-SHORTTITLE : values : text : CEEM Seminar Series | Youssef Hashash,X-BEDEWORK-ADDITIONAL-INFO : values : text : Autonomous machines, AI chat bots and preference algorithms, coupled with ubiquitous computing and persistent connectivity, the stuff of science fiction a few decades ago, are all around us. We are interacting with them on a daily basis, while they accumulate more information, learn and become more capable. As (geotechnical) engineers we face interesting questions in this new reality. Are these developments relevant to our field? Can we use them in our engineering practice? Will AI and Machine learning replace geotechnical engineers? Will the uncertainty inherent in geologic materials insulate us from the intrusion of these tools, rendering them a passing fad? In this presentation I will explore the application of modern tools of machine learning and AI to Geotechnical Engineering. By taking a historical perspective I highlight the data intensive and data rich nature of our discipline. I explore the application of artificial neural networks, and self learning algorithms to selected applications in tunneling, seismic site response, excavations and material testing. I will then explore the use of Generative AI for geotechnical design and report writing.

Bio:

Professor Youssef Hashash holds a B.S. (1987), an M.S. (1988) and a Ph.D. (1992) in civil engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He began his career with the PB/MK TEAM in Dallas on the Superconducting Super Collider Project. In 1994 he joined Parsons Brinckerhoff in San Francisco and worked on a number of underground construction projects in the U.S. and Canada including the Boston Central Artery/Tunnel project.

Professor Hashash joined the faculty of the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1998. He teaches courses in Geotechnical Engineering, Numerical Modeling in Geomechanics, Geotechnical Earthquake Engineering, Tunneling in Soil and Rock, and Excavation and Support Systems. His research focus includes deep excavations and tunneling in urban areas, earthquake engineering, continuum and discrete element modeling and soil-structure interaction as well as resiliency and sustainability of the built infrastructure. He also works on geotechnical engineering applications of deep learning, artificial intelligence, visualization, augmented reality, imaging and drone technologies. He has published numerous journal articles and is co-inventor on four patents. His research group developed the software program DEEPSOIL that is used worldwide for evaluation of soil response to earthquake shaking. His work on seismic design of underground structures is extensively used in engineering practice. He is the geotechnical co-leader of the NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology) led investigation into the Champlain Towers South Collapse in Surfside, Florida.

Professor Hashash is a Fellow of the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), a past president of the Geo-institute of ASCE and has received a number of teaching, university and professional awards including the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers and the ASCE 2014 Peck medal. He was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2022.

summary: Multi-Faith Fellowship
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Multi-Faith Fellowship provides the rare opportunity for genuine learning and community across faith traditions. Honesty, openness, and humility are core values that make the Multi-Faith Fellowship a unique experience in education and dialogue. Students from all schools and all traditions are welcome to join. Join us for&nbsp;dinner, discussion, and multi-faith dialogue every Wednesday night throughout the semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><a href="https://religiouslife.columbia.edu/content/multi-faith-fellowship" target="_blank">Learn more and apply to be a fellow here</a>.</p>

summary: Anti-Racism Speaker Series featuring Dr. Jolaade Kalinowski
locationaddress: Online Event
description: <h1><a href="https://columbiacuimc.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJErdOCuqz0rHt1bzLB1E1JskiSmZDZVKgm_" target="_blank"><strong>Register here via Zoom.</strong></a></h1>\n<p>This is the 8th Anti-Racism Speaker Serires event which&nbsp;will feature Dr. Jolaade Kalinowski, an Assistant Professor at UCONN.&nbsp;Her&nbsp;lecture, titled &ldquo;Stress Interventions as an Act of Resistance: Black Women&rsquo;s Health&rdquo;,&nbsp;will&nbsp;be held virtually on March 9th&nbsp;,&nbsp;2023..</p>\n<p>Dr. Kalinowski is an&nbsp;Assistant Professor in&nbsp;the Human Development and Family Sciences department at&nbsp;UCONN.&nbsp;Kalinowski is an alumna of Columbia University&rsquo;s Teachers College. She is&nbsp;behavioral cardiovascular researcher&nbsp;with&nbsp;interests including: the&nbsp;role of stress in cardiovascular health disparities, the role of ethnic identity on health, women&rsquo;s health, and social determinants of health.&nbsp;</p>

summary: Nurse Practitioner Workforce for Palliative Care
locationaddress: Online Event
categories: org/nursing,org/nursingCIPC,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Seminar,Online,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Clinical Health Sciences,Panel,Research,Postdocs,Government and Public Policy,Prospective Students,Healthcare,Graduate Students,College of Physicians and Surgeons,Columbia Nursing,Mailman School of Public Health,Trainees,Education,Communications / Media,org/cumc
description: <p>The Center for Improving Palliative Care for Vulnerable Adults with Multiple Chronic Conditions invites you to &quot;Nurse Practitioner Workforce for Palliative Care,&quot; a seminar presented by Dr. Lusine Poghosyan and Dr. Marian Grant. Dr.&nbsp;Poghosyan&nbsp;is the Stone Foundation and Elise D. Professor of&nbsp;Nursing at Columbia University School of Nursing and Professor of Health Policy and&nbsp;Management at the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University. Dr. Poghosyan is&nbsp;also the Executive Director of the Center for Healthcare Delivery Research and Innovations at&nbsp;Columbia University. Dr. Marian Grant&nbsp;is the Senior Regulatory Advisor for the <a href="https://www.thectac.org/" target="_blank">Coalition to Transform Advanced Care (C-TAC</a> , and a consultant for the <a href="https://www.capc.org/" target="_blank">Center to Advance Palliative Care (CAPC)</a>, the University of Washington&rsquo;s<a href="https://csupalliativecare.org/finding-the-right-messages-for-serious-illness-care/" target="_blank"> MessageLab Serious Illness Messaging project</a>, and <a href="https://www.vitaltalk.org/" target="_blank">VitalTalk</a>.</p>\n<p>Please register here:&nbsp;</p>\n<p><a href="https://columbiacuimc.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJIlf-mupzsoE9XhWSVOBsKvYB5WC3OPGLI8" target="_blank">https://columbiacuimc.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJIlf-mupzsoE9XhWSVOBsKvYB5WC3OPGLI8</a></p>

summary: Yoga Class
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Take a break to relax and refresh with yoga in Earl Hall. Free yoga classes (open level) will be offered in the Auditorium in Earl Hall every&nbsp;Thursday evening&nbsp;during the fall 2022 semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>No pre-registration required;&nbsp;open to all Columbia University students. Please bring your own mat and arrive 5-10 minutes early to sign in and set up.&nbsp;There is a 5 minute late policy, doors close at 7:05pm, or when the room has reached max capacity. 75 students maximum.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Please note that after spring break, the yoga classes will be offered from 5-6pm for the rest of the semester.&nbsp;</p>

summary: CTLgrads Office Hours (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>We invite current Columbia graduate student with&nbsp;questions about teaching&nbsp;to drop by office hours anytime today from 2:00&ndash;4:00 pm. We also welcome conversations about CTL fellowships, programs, services, job market preparation, and making progress in the Teaching Development Program (tdp.ctl.columbia.edu).</p>\n<p>No appointment is necessary; you can join us in-person in 212 Butler Library, or via Zoom at https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/my/ctlgrads.</p>\n<p>If&nbsp;you can&#39;t make office hours but want support, you can request an individual consultation at http://bit.ly/ctl-gradconsult or email us at CTLgrads@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: ISSO Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers Orientation
locationaddress: Online Event
description: <p>This ISSO sponsored event is for Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers at Columbia University.<br />\n<br />\nYou are invited to our Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers Orientation. These sessions are for those who have recently arrived. The orientation covers an overview of this visa status. ISSO strongly recommends you attend. Please have your DS-2019 and passport available. <a href="https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_kL4Yp_jTRIC0tzfoAdFSww" target="_blank">Register here</a>.</p>

summary: Monthly overview of IRI's Global Seasonal Climate Forecasts and ENSO status and forecast.
locationaddress: Online
description: The International Research Institute for Climate and Society (IRI) presents its climate forecast briefing. The IRI's seasonal, sub-seasonal and ENSO (El Niño Southern Oscillation) forecasts are discussed in this monthly briefing by IRI climate scientists Azhar Ehsan and Bohar Singh.\nFor more information, please see: https://iri.columbia.edu/our-expertise/climate/

summary: Understanding Open Access Publishing: Physical Sciences
locationaddress: Online Event
description: <p>Join us as our expert panel, James Hone, Wang Fong-Jen Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Chair of the Department of Mechanical Engineering, <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/teowaits/">Matteo Cavalleri</a>, Associate Editorial Director at WILEY, and <a href="https://library.columbia.edu/about/staff/sessl.html">Amanda Bielskas</a>, Director of the Science, Engineering, and Social Science Libraries, share their perspectives on and experience with academic publishing in the physical sciences.</p>

summary: Virtual Naloxone Training - Open to all Columbia affiliates
locationaddress: Online
description: <p>Columbia Health is a Registered Opioid Overdose Prevention Program, recognized by New York City and State Departments of Health. This designation came as part of a collaboration with researchers from the Mailman School of Public Health and the School of General Studies. As part of this work, Columbia Health is offering virtual Naloxone training via Zoom to members of the Columbia University community. Naloxone kits&nbsp;can be picked up from Columbia Health or mailed to participants upon completion of training.&nbsp;If you would like to learn more about the training, please visit&nbsp;<a href="https://health.columbia.edu/content/naloxone-training">https://health.columbia.edu/content/naloxone-training</a>.</p>\n<p>Registration required.</p>\n<p><strong>Register for the March 17, 1:00 &ndash; 2:00 PM ET&nbsp;session:</strong> <a href="https://nam02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2F3JgK3Tw&amp;data=05%7C01%7Chealthcomm%40cumc.columbia.edu%7C8181feafa6984fd8392408daff142e40%7Cb0002a9b0017404d97dc3d3bab09be81%7C0%7C0%7C638102759384295319%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&amp;sdata=E%2BR%2FbyjMHpzw02bQ8y6B%2B5Q%2Fu9mVGkRROqlMQIHqNYw%3D&amp;reserved=0">https://bit.ly/3JgK3Tw</a></p>

summary: CTLgrads Office Hours (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>We invite current Columbia graduate student with&nbsp;questions about teaching&nbsp;to drop by office hours anytime today from 2:00&ndash;4:00 pm. We also welcome conversations about CTL fellowships, programs, services, job market preparation, and making progress in the Teaching Development Program (tdp.ctl.columbia.edu).</p>\n<p>No appointment is necessary; you can join us in-person in 212 Butler Library, or via Zoom at https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/my/ctlgrads.</p>\n<p>If&nbsp;you can&#39;t make office hours but want support, you can request an individual consultation at http://bit.ly/ctl-gradconsult or email us at CTLgrads@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: World Water Film Festival
locationaddress: The Forum at Columbia University, 601 W. 125th St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The World Water Film Festival will showcase a variety of 20 short and feature films made by water advocates from around the world, featuring workshops, guest speakers, and a 4-hour &quot;Women in Water Energy &amp; Film&quot; summit led by Youth for Global Health &amp; Social Justice founder, Dr.&nbsp;Sheryl Simmons.</p>\n<p><strong>More information and registration details are available on the World Water Film Festival website:&nbsp;<a href="https://worldwaterff.org/" target="_blank">https://worldwaterff.org/&nbsp;</a></strong></p>

description: <p>Join us for the next session of the <a href="https://www.gca.cuimc.columbia.edu/community-service-programs/school-district-collaborations/community-school-district-6" target="_blank">Community School District 6 Health and Wellness Series</a>. The goal of the virtual event series is&nbsp;to provide helpful information and practical resources about a range of topics of interest to the school community.</p>\n<p>This session&nbsp;&quot;Empower, Educate, and Support LGBTQIA2+ Families and Friends&quot; will be lead by clinical psychologists Jae S. Cha, PsyD, and Hugh T. Love, PhD.</p>\n<p><strong>Join the webinar: <a href="http://Join the webinar: https://zoom.us/j/98569828455?pwd=OEpId3o3cEZVdjBQWVNoZm5BVThUZz09#success" target="_blank">https://zoom.us/j/98569828455?pwd=OEpId3o3cEZVdjBQWVNoZm5BVThUZz09#success</a></strong></p>

summary: Guided Historical Tour
locationaddress: Low Library, 535 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Tour,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Guided Historical Tour,Visitors Center,org/visitorscenter,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees
description: <p>Join this tour to learn more about the history, architecture, and sculpture of Columbia and the Morningside Heights campus. Whether you&#39;re an amateur New York City historian or visiting campus for the first time, you will leave the tour knowing more about our storied past.</p>\n<p>Tours will depart from the Visitors Center, located in Room 213 in Low Library.&nbsp;Please arrive at least 15 minutes prior to the tour time. Tours take place rain or shine. We encourage guests to dress appropriately based upon the weather conditions of their visit day.</p>\n<p>All Visitors Center visitors are required to bring proof of a primary vaccination series to their campus tour. A list of acceptable documentation can be found <a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/content/faqs-regarding-covid-19-vaccination#!#%2Fcu_accordion_item-4780" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>

summary: One-year MS in Human Nutrition Program Webinar
locationaddress: Online Event
categories: Medical Center,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Webcast,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Basic Health Sciences,Clinical Health Sciences,Postdocs,org/cumc_ihn,Admissions,Prospective Students,Healthcare,Graduate Students,College of Physicians and Surgeons,Columbia Nursing,Mailman School of Public Health,Trainees,Education,org/EI,org/cumc
description: <p>The <strong>1-year Columbia MS in Human Nutrition</strong> involves an intense year of study; thesis research with options in basic nutrition science, clinical nutrition, and public health nutrition; and preparation for medical school, as well as a broad range of new and important healthcare careers.</p>\n<p>Join our webinar and alumni panel discussion, where Institute faculty, staff, and alumni will&nbsp;provide an overview of our one-year MS in Human Nutrition program with insights on career paths and program highlights from the alumni.&nbsp;The session will close with a Q&amp;A. Click &#39;Register for the Webinar&#39; above to register. We look forward to speaking with you.</p>

summary: The Importance of Unplugging in a Virtual World
locationaddress: Online
description: <p>In today&rsquo;s world of remote work, the lines between work and home are more blurred than ever as technology allows us to be constantly connected. In this seminar we will discuss the impact of being connected 24/7 and the benefits of unplugging. You will get some tips on how to take action to unplug from work and reconnect to your life.</p>\n<p>Presenter: Facilitator from LifeWorks (Columbia University&rsquo;s Employee Assistance Program)&nbsp;</p>
